Electric field promoted oxidation of naphthalene over Cu/Ce0.55Zr0.45O x catalysts at low temperature Feixiang Shen Ke Li Dejun Xu Ruining Yan Ting Chen Reggie Zhan He Lin ⁎ The Key Laboratory for Power Machinery and Engineering of the Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 200240, Shanghai, PR China The Key Laboratory for Power Machinery and Engineering of the Ministry of Education Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Dongchuan Road No.800, Min Hang District, 200240, Shanghai, PR China. Dongchuan Road No.800 Min Hang District Shanghai 200240 PR China Graphical abstract Electric field was applied into the catalytic oxidation for the naphthalene over m% Cu/Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 catalysts. It was found that catalysts with 2% Cu loading exhibit the best catalytic performance and complete naphthalene conversion was achieved at low temperature of 150 °C. The effect of Cu modification and electric field were thoroughly investigated with various characterization technologies. It was found that the doping of Cu to Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 support is beneficial for the oxygen availability and regeneration capability, but suppressive for the naphthalene adsorption. Without electric field, the oxygen availability is the rate determining factor since the oxidation of adsorbed naphthalene on the catalyst surface is the lowest compared with the adsorption and oxygen regeneration process. Under the electric field, the conduction of electricity is through the occupation and reformation of oxygen vacancies by O ion, leading to highly improved oxygen mobility in the catalyst lattice. In addition, the formed Ce3+ in the electric field can easily be re-oxidized by the adjacent CuO, making oxygen species in CuO available for the naphthalene oxidation. Thus the catalytic performance was promoted due to the improved oxygen availability in the electric field and the optimized Cu loading is a balance between the adsorption ability and regeneration capability. Keywords Electric field Naphthalene oxidation Adsorption capacity Oxygen availability Oxygen regeneration capability 1 Introduction Recently, abatement of volatile organic compound (VOC) has been a hot research topic due to its contribution on air pollution and human health [1]. Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs), a typical group from VOC classifications, is suggested as carcinogenic pollutants and associated with serious health hazards [2–5]. The exhaust of diesel engine is an important source of PAHs due to incomplete combustion of fossil oil [6–8]. With the increasingly strict environmental legislation, the elimination of PAHs is becoming a tremendous challenge facing the research scholars [9–11]. Among the classification of PAH, naphthalene is considered as one of the most abundant PAHs in flue gases, and usually suggested to be a model molecule for research due to its most volatile property. Extensive investigation on catalytic oxidation for naphthalene have been made in the last decades [1,2,6,7,12–30]. Supported noble metal catalysts have been proved to exhibit high conversion for low-temperature oxidation of naphthalene [18,28–36]. Nevertheless, increasing attention is being paid to transitional metal based catalysts which are relatively more cost-effective. Mn, Co, Cu and Ce oxides, have been suggested as good candidates for naphthalene abatement [12,15,24,37–42]. However, those non-noble metal based catalysts reported in most studies can hardly realize the complete conversion of naphthalene below 200 °C, which is limited in applications for many PAH resources such as diesel engine exhaust during the cold start period with temperature ranging from 150 to 200 °C. Thus, more effort should be focused on further improving activity of non-noble catalysts. Recently, Y. Sekine’s group reported a new-type catalytic technology applying electric field on conventional reaction system [43–57]. They found enhanced catalytic activity for methane reforming and oxidative coupling with the assistance of electric field [47,52]. In our previous study [58–60], we applied this electric field assisted system on methane combustion over Co-Ce-Zr and Mn-Co series catalysts, and the results shows that the methane light off temperature is around 250 °C over the tested non-noble based catalysts. It was found that the electric field promote the oxygen mobility in catalysts support and formation of active sites for methane chemisorption and activation, leading to high conversion rate at low temperature. However, further application of this catalytic technology on oxidation of other hydrocarbon has not been studied. In this work, we aim to improve naphthalene oxidation at low temperature over non-noble catalysts with electric field assisted catalytic system. Among all non-noble oxides, Copper-doped ceria mixed oxide is demonstrated as versatile catalyst for total oxidation of hydrocarbon and VOCs and has been investigated in heterogeneous catalysis system for many years [24,40,61–67]. It is generally recognized that the doping of copper into CeO2 oxides can enhance the oxygen storage capacity and promote formation of structural defects on catalyst surface, leading to high catalytic performance even as well as noble metals based catalysts [24,61–68]. Larsson’s group investigate the oxidation of ethanol and ethyl acetate over CuO-CeO2/TiO2 catalysts and found the interaction between CeO2 and CuO lead to enhanced reducibility [69]. Aranda et al. have investigated naphthalene over CuO-CeO2 catalysts, they revealed that surface oxygen defects play a vital role for naphthalene oxidation [38]. They found that the proper dopping of Cu is beneficial for catalytic performance, however, the temperature demanded for complete oxidation of naphthalene is still higher than 200 °C. Thus it is necessary to further improve the activity with electric field assisted catalytic system. In our previous study [58,59], the mobility of oxygen species in CeO2 was promoted under electric field, giving rise to formation of more active sites on the catalyst surface. However, the CeO2 oxide exhibit a high electric resistance which can lead to a high power consumption in the electric promoted system. The inclusion of Zr cations in CeO2 lattice forming solid solutions can significantly reduce the resistance as well as improve dispersion of supported metal. Therefore, it is promising to realize the naphthalene oxidation at low temperature over Cu/Ce x Zr1- x O2 catalysts with the application of electric field. In this work, a series of Cu/Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 catalysts with different Cu loading was investigated under electric field promoted catalytic system for naphthalene complete oxidation. The interaction between electric field application and catalytic activity were thoroughly studied with XRD, XPS, BET, NAP-TPD and H2-TPR experiment. The effect of Cu modification and electric field for naphthalene oxidation was intrinsically clarified. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalyst samples The Cu/Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 catalyst samples were prepared through solution combustion method [70]. The solution precursor was prepared by mixture of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O. And the Glycine (CH2NH2COOH) was added into the solution to neutralize nitrates. The mixture was stirred on a plate until smooth and subsequently decanted into a corundum crucible, which was placed in a muffle furnace maintained at 700 ℃ for 4 h. After end of burning the residue cooled to room temperature and gathered up. After sieved to 40–60 meshes, the obtained samples were named n% Cu, in which n is the mole percent of doped copper. To investigate the effect of the electric field on the catalyst by characterization techniques that cannot perform online, such as XRD, TEM and XPS experiment, the samples was treated in N2 at 175 ℃ for 2 h in electric field and termed as treated n% Cu. 2.2 Catalytic performance The catalyst evaluation tests for naphthalene oxidation was conducted in a micro flow reactor. As illustrated in Fig. 1 , a DC power supply was applied to generate electric field which was introduced into the system through platinum wire electrodes placed on the catalyst bed. The input current was controllable while the voltage lied on the electrical resistance of the tested sample. The gaseous naphthalene was generated from solid phase through an evaporator maintained at 50 °C. The feeding reactants consisted of 100 ppm naphthalene and 10 vol% O2 balanced by N2. The total volumetric flow rate is 150 ml/min (gas space velocity is 60,000 h−1). The thermocouple contacting with catalyst bed is used to measure the actual temperature of the catalyst under electric field. The concentrations of naphthalene and CO2 in the outlet gas were respectively measured with Gas chromatography and FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Nicolet is10). The catalytic performance was expressed as the naphthalene rate (CC10H8) and yield of CO2 (SCO2), which were defined as: (1) CC10H8 = ([C10H8]in-[C10H8]out) /[C10H8]in (2) SCO2 = [CO2]out /10[C10H8]in Where [C10H8]in and [C10H8]out are inlet and outlet molar concentration of naphthalene, and [CO2]out is the outlet molar concentration of CO2. Turnover frequency (TOF) and TOF gain over electric power (ΔTOF*) was also calculated to evaluate the activity of Cu sites and promotion of electric field, the calculation is according to the following equations: (3) TOF = ( [C 10 H 8 ] in -[C 10 H 8 ] out ) •V /(M×D ) (4) ΔTOF* = ΔTOF/P where V is the volume flow rate, M is the mole number of Cu loading on the catalyst, and D is the dispersion of Cu, ΔTOF* is the yield of TOF with the electric field, P is the input electric power. Besides, to quantify the efficiency of electric field, η value was defined as (5) η = 24 • additional reacted C 10 H 8 molecules in electric field/input electrons Where 24 represents that the number of electron transfer in complete oxidation of one C10H8 molecule. 2.3 Characterization technology The surface areas were collected on Quantachrome NOVA 2000e Automated Gas Sorption Instrument. The adsorption test is conducted at 77 K using N2 as the adsorbate. Before the samples analysis, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 300 °C for 4 h to remove the impurities. Specific surface areas of the catalysts were measured through the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The crystal structures of the samples were analyzed by Powder X-ray Diffraction (XRD, D8 ADVANCE Da Vinci) using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5406 Å). XRD profiles were obtained over 2θ ranging from 20° to 80° and the crystal size of the catalyst was detemined through Scherrer equation. The elemental compositions of the catalysts surface were analyzed with an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), which was performed on a Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD spectrometer. The C 1s spectra were collected from 278 to 298 eV, Cu 2p from 923 to 958 eV, and Ce 3d from 330 to 350 eV, O 1s from 765 to 815 eV. Naphthalene temperature-programmed desorption was carried out to obtain the naphthalene adsorption capacity of the catalysts. The samples (100 mg) were first treated in N2 flow at 400 °C for 1 h. Then the catalysts were cooled to 100 °C and exposed to gas mixture containing 100 ppm C10H8/N2 for 1 h until saturation of adsorption capacity. Then the catalysts were flushed with N2 for 30 min, and heated from 100 to 350 °C at a ramp of 10 °C/min. The NAP-TPD profiles were obtained with by GC–FID. H2-TPR tests were conducted on Micromeritics Chemisorb 2720 equipment to study the reducibility of the samples. The sample was first treated in N2 at 600 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to room temperature. To further investigate regeneration of oxygen species on the catalyst defect, the following procedure was used as proposed by Xiaodong Wu et al [12]. • The H2-TPR was conducted from 100 °C to 800 °C at a ramp of 10 °C/min exposed to gas mixture of 5% H2/N2. The data collected in this procedure was studied to evaluate the oxygen availability and reducibility of catalysts. • Repeat the above procedure for another two times until the consumption of H2 was not detected. The oxygen species on the catalyst was all consumed and migration from bulk oxygen was drastically inhibited. • The oxygen regeneration was conducted by heating the samples up from 100 °C to 300 °C at a ramp of 10 °C/min exposed to gas mixture of 10% O2 and 95% N2. Then the first procedure was repeated, and the H2 consumption in this procedure can reflect the regeneration of oxygen species in the catalyst from gaseous oxygen. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst performance The conversion curves for naphthalene oxidation are illustrated in Fig. 2 . The results demonstrated an impressive increase of naphthalene conversion efficiency with electric field. The total naphthalene oxidation can be achieved at temperature range of 150 °C–200 °C over the Cu doped catalysts. Without assistance of electric field, the influence of Cu loading on oxidation activity is impressive with the catalytic performance order 2% Cu > 4% Cu>1% Cu > 0.5% Cu > 8% Cu. This indicates that overloading of Cu will lead to a decrease in the activity and Asunción Aranda et al got the similar results over CuO-CeO2 catalysts. With the assistance of electric field, catalysts with 4% Cu loading exhibit the highest activity with naphthalene being completely eliminated at 171 °C. The activity order changes to 4% Cu > 2% Cu > 8% Cu > 1% Cu > 0.5% Cu. It demonstrated that the promotion of electric field on naphthalene oxidation is not simple stacking of the conversion value, but dependent on the structure and surface composition of the catalyst. The Cu dispersion of the catalysts, as listed in Table 1 , exhibit a tight correlation with the Cu loading percent. The Cu dispersion was very low in 0.5% Cu and 1% Cu, indicating that most of the Cu species was incorporated in the catalyst bulk. And the low Cu dispersion will lead to low TOF value. As shown in Fig. 3 , the TOF value of 8% Cu in the electric field was relatively lower than 4% Cu and 2% Cu. However, the TOF gain over electric power (ΔTOF*) reached highest over catalysts with 8% Cu loading. This is mainly due to the lowest electrical resistance and poorest performance of 8% Cu without the electric field. Thus the proper Cu loading (4%) is the balance between the promotion of electric field and oxidation ability of the catalysts alone. And the 4% Cu can realize the total oxidation of naphthalene at nearly 150 °C in the electric field, which is even superior to noble based catalysts reported in literatures. In our previous study [59] about Co-Ce-Zr catalysts for methane oxidation, a similar trend is also observed with the top TOF values obtained over 25% Co loading, indicating that the promotion of electric field may be independent of reactants. Fig. 3 also shows the slight change of input power over catalysts with various Cu loading. The catalyst resistance is mainly determined by the Ce0.55Zr0.45 support. Table 1 listed the η value calculated according to Eq. (3) at 150 °C. The η value should be 1 if the reaction was promoted electrochemically. However, the η value is much higher than 1, indicating that the reaction was promoted catalytically rather than electrochemically, and this is in good consistence with conclusion proposed by Yasushi Sekine’s group [44]. Fig. 4 a illustrates the CO2 selectivity column with naphthalene conversion rate of 20%. Although the CO2 selectivity was high than 90%, there are still other incomplete combustion products such as CO, dimethyl phthalate, benzaldehyde et al, which can be more poisonous and environmentally harmful naphthalene. So the CO2 selectivity is also an important target in the catalyst evaluation. With the assistance of electric field, the selectivity to CO2 decreased to below 90%, which may be due to that the 20% naphthalene conversion occurred at a rather low temperature under electric field, making it hard for complete oxidation of the by-products. Similar phenomenon can also be observed in the CO2 selectivity column at 50% and 90% naphthalene conversion, as shown in Fig. 4b and c. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of fresh n% CuCe0.55Zr0.45O2 catalyst samples are illustrated in Fig. 5 a. The reflections of pure Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 samples mainly located at 28.28°, 33.95°, 48.82°, 58.02°, 60.88° and 76.70°, corresponding to (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (2 2 2) and (3 3 1) planes of the Ce-Zr-O solid solution. Those diffraction peaks shifted to higher degree with increase of Cu loading. No peaks of Cu or CuO were observed over the profiles of samples with Cu loading lower than 8%. This indicates a good dispersion of Cu oxides and formation of solid solution, which will enhance the interaction between the Cu oxides and Ce0.55Zr0.45O x support [71]. The lattice parameter of the catalysts decreased slightly, as shown in Table 2 , further proving the incorporation of Cu species in the Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 lattice due to smaller size of coordinated Cu+ and Cu2+ than Ce3+ or Ce4+ [68,71]. Weak diffraction reflections at 35.4° and 38.9°, ascribed to the structure of bulk CuO were detected for sample with 8% Cu loading [68], which is not beneficial for the catalytic activity. The XRD profiles of treated samples, as shown in Fig. 5b, exhibit a shift of Ce0.55Zr0.45O x related reflections to lower degree. Besides, the treated samples had a smaller lattice parameter compared with fresh samples, which may be account of the reduction of Ce4+ in solid solution to Ce3+ in the electric field. No obvious differences was observed over diffraction reflections of bulk CuO, indicating that the change of Cu species in the electric field may occur over the Cu ions in the solid solution, which cannot be found by the XRD experiment. Fig. 6 illustrates TEM images of fresh and treated n% Cu samples. The average particle size of fresh sample decreased slightly with doping of Cu, indicating that incorporation of Cu ions into fluorite lattice was conducive to decrease of the crystalline size. This can be attributed to the smaller radius of six coordinated Cu2+ (0.073 nm) compared with Ce4+ (0.10 nm) and Zr4+ (0.084 nm). After treated under electric field, the samples exhibited a lower particle size, which is due to the reduction of CeO2 under electric field. The HRTEM morphologies of the samples are shown in Fig. 7 . The d spacing values of 0.312 nm, 0.310 nm and 0.308 nm were ascribed to the (103) plain of CeO2 particles, Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 and Cu-Ce-Zr-O solid solution, respectively. No lattice fringe of Cu-Ce-Zr-O solid solution was observed on samples with 0.5% Cu loading, which may be due to low content of Cu. Lattice fringes of 0.272 nm as shown in Fig. 7c and e was attributed to the (1 1 1) plane of CuO, in good agreement with results from XRD experiment. This observation means that the Cu species in catalysts mainly exists in two phases, the CuO oxide and the Cu-Ce-Zr-O solid solution. The incorporation of Cu into Ce0.55Zr0.45 is limited and high Cu loading will lead to formation of CuO bulk on catalyst surface, which is less active in the naphthalene oxidation, accounting for the poor performance of 8% Cu. The d spacing values of Ce related solid solution decreased slightly after the sample was treated in the electric field, and this can be explained by the incorporation of Ce3+ in the solid solution. 3.3 XPS spectra The XPS spectra were obtained to investigate the surface characteristics of the n% CuCe0.55Zr0.45O2 catalysts. Fig. 8 a illustrated the Ce 3d spectra of the fresh and treated samples. The spectra was resolved into eight asymmetric peak, and the peaks at 883.9 eV, 888.9 eV, 897.8 eV, 903.1 eV, 907.8 eV and 916.7 eV were characteristic features of Ce4+, and the other two at 885.6 eV and 903.8 eV were corresponding to Ce3+ species [40,65]. The ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ is generally accepted as an important indicator to evaluate the amount of oxygen vacancies, which are highly associated to catalyst performance [60,72]. As shown in Table 3 , there is no direct relation between surface Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio and Cu loading percent over 0.5% and 1% Cu. The decrease of Ce3+ content with Cu loading over 2% Cu, 4% Cu and 8% Cu may be owning to the formation of highly dispersed CuO that can re-oxidize Ce3+ on the catalyst surface. Compared with fresh samples, the treated samples has a higher Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio, indicating the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ under electric field. Since the electric conduction of the fluorite structure is through the occupation of oxygen vacancies by O ion and reformation of new oxygen vacancies, which is typical for oxide semiconductor, the CeO2 can easily lose O ion in the electric field and undergo a valence decrease. Fig. 8b indicated the Cu spectra of fresh and treated 2%, 4% and 8% Cu samples. And the intensity of spectra over sample with Cu loading lower than 2% were not clear enough to be observed, indicating the complete incorporation of Cu in the fluorite structure. The Cu signal can be resolved into two asymmetric peaks of Cu 2p3/2 centered at 934.3 eV and Cu2p1/2 centered at 954.1 eV. The principal peaks at 934.0 eV and 953.7 eV can be identified as Cu2+, whereas the shake-up peak at the range of 940.1 eV–945.1 eV is attributed to Cu+ [71]. The simultaneous presence of Cu+ and Cu2+ can be attributed to the partly reduction of dispersed Cu2+ by Ce3+ on catalyst surface. And the Cu+ content is much lower in 8% Cu sample due to formation of bulk CuO species. Compared with fresh samples, the treated samples showed a higher Cu+ content, indicating that the formation of more Ce3+ in the electric field led to further reduction of the Cu2+. The O 1s spectra shown in Fig. 8c could be fitted into two main peaks. The binding energy in the region of 529.6 − 529.9 eV was corresponding to oxygen from the catalyst lattice (OL), and the other centered at 531.0 − 531.5 eV was assigned to surface chemisorbed oxygen (OA). Over the fresh catalysts, The ratio of OA/(OL+ OA) followed the order 0.5% Cu < 1% Cu < 2% Cu ≈ 4% Cu ≈ 8% Cu. This demonstrates that incorporation of Cu in the lattice can weaken the Ce-O bonds, promoting conversion of OL to OA. However, there is a limitation of Cu incorporation [40] and more dispersed CuO or Cu2O and even bulk CuO formed on the catalysts with Cu loading higher than 2%, leading to no longer increase of the OA content. Over the treated catalysts, the ratio of OA/(OL+OA) increased significantly compared with fresh catalysts and the sequence turned to 0.5% Cu < 1% Cu < 2% Cu < 4% Cu ≈ 8% Cu. It can be deduced that the electric field facilitate the OA formation through boosting Ce4+ reduction, and the dispersed CuO can provide lattice oxygen vacancies through the re-oxidation of Ce3+. Thus an indirect transformation path of O species from dispersed CuO to surface chemisorbed oxygen OA was formed in the electric field through the equations below: (6) Ce 2 O 3 +2 CuO →2 Ce O 2 + Cu 2 O (7) 2Ce O 2 + e - → Ce 2 O 3 + O - And the similar OA/(OL+ OA) ratio of 4% Cu and 8% Cu indicated a limitation of dispersed CuO on the catalyst surface. 3.4 H2-TPR H2-temperature-programed Reduction tests were conducted to probe reducibility of the samples with and without the electric field. As mentioned in Part 2.3, the H2 consumption profile of the first and last procedure were recorded to investigate the oxygen availability and regeneration capability of tested samples. Fig. 9 a shows the results of fresh catalysts in the first procedure. The Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 profile consisted of two reduction peaks centered around 421 °C and 629 °C, attributed to reduction of chemisorbed oxygen species on catalyst surface and lattice oxygen (Ce4+→Ce3+). Over the samples with Cu loading, a new bimodal shape of peaks centered from 130 °C to 215 °C was detected, corresponding to the Cu2+ → Cu+ and Cu+ → Cu reduction [68,71]. According to Table 4 , the calculated H2 consumption for Cu oxides was much higher than theoretical consumption and did not increase linearly with the Cu loading. This suggests that the formation of the reductive peak was only partly due to Cu oxides. The reduction of Ce4+ nearby Cu oxides may occur at similar temperature, which contributed most to the formation of the peaks centered from 130 °C to 215 °C. Thus this low temperature-peak reflects the availability of oxygen atom in the Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 lattice. And the oxygen availability can be promoted with Cu loading due to the weakened Ce-O bond caused by the incorporation of Cu ion. And the sequence of oxygen availability is 0.5% Cu < 1% Cu < 2% Cu ≈ 4% Cu ≈ 8% Cu. Fig. 9b illustrates the H2-TPR profiles over n% CuCe0.55Zr0.45O2 with electric field. For Ce0.55Zr0.45O2, both peaks of chemisorbed active oxygen and lattice oxygen (Ce4+→Ce3+) was significantly broadened and the latter shifted to lower temperature, indicating a highly enhanced availability of O atom from the lattice in the electric field. Similarly, for samples with Cu loading, both peaks of Cu2+ → Cu+ and Cu+ → Cu shifted two lower temperature and the calculated H2 consumption become much higher than the theoretical H2 consumption from Cu oxides, further proving the fact that the effect of the electric field is to increase the oxygen availability by promoting the CeO2 reduction. The oxygen availability turned to 0.5% Cu < 1% Cu < 2% Cu < 4% Cu ≈8% Cu, indicating that formed highly dispersed CuO in catalysts with high Cu loading is also beneficial for the generation of oxygen species in electric field. Fig. 10 illustrates the H2-TPR profiles over n% CuCe0.55Zr0.45O2 in the last procedure. Since the oxygen species on the catalyst was all consumed and migration of oxygen atoms from CeO2 bulk is drastically inhibited in the former three H2-TPR processes, H2 consumption in this procedure was attributed to regenerated oxygen during the pre-oxidizing experiment. There is no clear differences between the profiles in Fig. 10a and b, indicating that electric field exhibit no influence in regeneration process. The profile of the Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 sample is almost flat, while the samples with Cu loading exhibit an impressive oxygen regeneration. It can be speculated that the gaseous oxygen would chemisorbed on dispersed Cu sites and the formed CuO and Cu2O would further oxidized Ce3+ and supplemented the consumed oxygen species. The samples with 8% Cu loading shows a relatively lower oxygen regeneration ability, indicating that the bulk CuO is not involved in the regeneration process. The adsorption of the reactants is always suggested as a necessary step in heterogeneous reaction. The Nap-TPD experiment was carried out to evaluate the naphthalene adsorption capability of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 11 a, the naphthalene desorption profiles of Cu doped catalysts exhibit two main peaks at 200 °C and 270 °C, corresponding to weakly physical adsorption and strongly chemisorption of naphthalene. Both peaks decreased with the rise of Cu loading, indicating that presence of Cu could inhibit adsorption capability of the catalysts. It was reported that naphthalene adsorption was determined by the specific surface area and pore structure of the ceria oxide support. It can be concluded that Cu did not act as an adsorption sites for naphthalene, and the loading of Cu could cover up part of ceria oxide surface, leading to the weakened naphthalene adsorption capability. As shown in Fig. 11b, the low temperature adsorption peak intensity exhibited no obvious change in the electric field compared with that in Fig. 11a. However, the high temperature adsorption peak was not observed, thus resulting in a decreased naphthalene desorption quantity with assistance of the electric field, as shown in Table 3. This can be explained that the adsorbed naphthalene may reacted with the oxygen species from the catalyst at high temperature, since the mobility of the oxygen species is highly promoted in electric field. And the produced CO and CO2 was detected in the NAP-TPD process, as shown in Fig. S4. 3.5 Discussion Naphthalene catalytic oxidation has been investigated intensely by many groups and it is widely accepted that this reaction may follow the Mars van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [12,25,27,38,40,73]. The gaseous naphthalene will first adsorb on the catalyst and then reacted with the O* from the support lattice, the remaining oxygen vacancies in the lattice will be regenerated from the gaseous oxygen. It can be summarized that the catalytic activity for naphthalene catalytic oxidation was highly dependent on the adsorption capacity, oxygen availability and regeneration capability of catalysts. The role of Cu species and electric field in the reaction should be intensely discussed from these three aspects. 3.5.1 Naphthalene adsorption Generally, active adsorptive centers are demanded for the adsorption of reactants. The NAP-TPD results shows that the adsorption capacity of the samples weakened with the increasing Cu loading, demonstrating that the naphthalene adsorption may mainly occurs on Ce-Zr sites. Based on the XRD and TEM experiment, most of Cu species in 0.5% Cu and 1% Cu samples was merged in the Ce-Zr-O lattice; and there are two different phases present in 2% Cu and 4% Cu samples, i.e. Cu-Ce-Zr-O solid solution and highly dispersed Cu species (Cu0, Cu+ and Cu2+); in samples with higher Cu loading of 8% the bulk CuO will be formed because of the limitation of dispersed Cu species on catalysts surface. Since 0.5% Cu and 1% Cu exhibit similar adsorption capability with 0% Cu, the inhabitation of Cu species on the adsorption of naphthalene can be caused by the dispersed and bulk CuO on catalysts surface that reduced exposure of active adsorptive centers on the Ce0.55Zr0.45O x . There is no significant change on the adsorption capability of samples under electric field. Thus the effect of electric field on naphthalene adsorption could be ignored. The disappearance of the high temperature desorption peak indicates that the adsorbed naphthalene reacted with the oxygen species from the catalysts due to enhanced oxygen availability under electric field, which will be further discussed in the following paragraph. 3.5.2 Oxygen availability and regeneration capability According to MvK mechanism, the oxygen species that involved in the naphthalene oxidation mainly root from the catalyst bulk rather than the gaseous oxygen. Thus the consumption and regeneration of oxygen species in the catalysts constitute an important cycle that may be rate determining in naphthalene oxidation. It is accepted that Ce oxide is a good oxygen storage material with the supply and regeneration of oxygen species proceeding easily through Ce3+/Ce4+ redox cycling. Results in this study indicate that the Cu ions in the catalyst lattice can weaken CeO bond, leading to high oxygen availability for the reaction. Asunción Aranda [40] also reported the relation between the incorporation of Cu and formation of oxygen defects over copper-doped ceria catalysts. However, the promotion effect is limited and the formed dispersed and bulk CuO on the catalyst surface with higher Cu loading are not beneficial for the release of bulk oxygen. Thus the oxygen availability order is 0.5% Cu < 1% Cu < 2% Cu ≈ 4% Cu ≈ 8% Cu. With the assistance of electric field, the oxygen mobility was significantly enhanced due to the improved Ce4+ reduction under electric field. The incorporation of Zr ion in CeO2 lattice create oxygen defects and vacancies, which will make room for the motivation of oxygen ions in the fluorite structure under the external electric field. Thus oxygen mobility is highly improved with CeO2 easily losing O ion. In addition, the reduction of Ce4+ produced more Ce3+, which can be oxidized by the dispersed CuO, making the O species in CuO available for the oxidation of naphthalene through the Eqs. (6) and (7). However, the oxygen availability order of 0.5% Cu < 1% Cu < 2% Cu < 4% Cu ≈8% Cu indicates that the oxygen in bulk CuO can hardly be involved in the naphthalene oxidation. The regeneration of the consumed oxygen species is essentially the Ce3+ re-oxidation process, which is evaluated by the specially designed H2-TPR test. The impressive regeneration capability of 2% Cu and 4% Cu indicates that dispersed Cu species played a vital role in re-oxidation of reduced catalysts. It can be populated that the dispersed CuO or Cu2O will oxidize concomitant Ce3+, and the reduced Cu sites will chemisorb the gaseous oxygen and get back to the original state. Thus the dispersed Cu species acted as a connection bridge between the reduced catalyst support and gaseous oxygen. The influence of electric field on oxygen regeneration capability could be ignored. In conclusion, the incorporation of Cu species in the bulk lattice can improve the oxygen availability, the dispersed Cu species are beneficial for the oxygen regeneration, but suppressive for the naphthalene adsorption, which is also inhibited by the bulk CuO. The catalytic activity is mainly dependent on the “weakest link” among naphthalene adsorption, oxygen availability and regeneration capability. According to the performance results, the oxygen availability is the most decisive factor for m% Cu/Ce0.55Zr0.45O x catalysts, as shown in Fig. 12 a. Xiaodong Wu et al [12] investigated the naphthalene oxidation on Ag/CeO2 and get similar conclusion that the effect of adsorption ability on the naphthalene oxidation was negligible. However, with assistance of electric field, the oxygen mobility is significantly enhanced due to the improved Ce4+ reduction, leading to a substantial improvement on catalytic activity of naphthalene oxidation, as shown in Fig. 12b, and the optimized Cu loading (2%) is a balance between the adsorption ability and regeneration capability. 4 Conclusions Low temperature oxidation of naphthalene was realized over n% Cu/Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 catalysts. 2% Cu/Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 exhibits the highest activity with the complete conversion of naphthalene at 171 °C. With thorough investigation on the naphthalene adsorption capacity, oxygen availability and regeneration capability, which are important factors in Mars van Krevelen model, the mechanism of Cu modification and electric field promotion on the catalytic activity are summarized as follows: Cu species introduced to the Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 mainly exists in three different phases: incorporated Cu ion in Cu-Ce-Zr-O solid solution, dispersed CuO and bulk CuO particles. The first phase can promote oxygen availability by weakening the Ce-O bond, while the second phase is beneficial for the oxygen regeneration through re-oxidation of Ce3+ by Cu2+ and Cu+, but suppressive for the naphthalene adsorption due to the cover of surface adsorptive centers. The bulk CuO can also reduce the adsorption ability of the catalyst through similar way. The catalytic activity is mainly dependent on the oxygen availability since the oxidation of naphthalene is much slower than the adsorption and regeneration process. The electric field can significantly improve the oxygen availability due to the improved Ce4+ reduction. The mobility of O ion through oxygen defects and vacancies in the catalyst lattice is accelerated in the external electric field. Furthermore, the oxygen species in adjacent CuO were also involved in the oxidation process through re-oxidation of the increased Ce3+ in the electric field. The increased oxygen availability lead to highly promoted performance for naphthalene, and the optimized Cu loading is a balance between the adsorption ability and regeneration capability. coredata.dc:description: Electric field was applied into the catalytic oxidation for the naphthalene over m% Cu/Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 catalysts. It was found that catalysts with 2% Cu loading exhibit the best catalytic performance and complete naphthalene conversion was achieved at low temperature of 150 °C. The effect of Cu modification and electric field were thoroughly investigated with various characterization technologies. It was found that the doping of Cu to Ce0.55Zr0.45O2 support is beneficial for the oxygen availability and regeneration capability, but suppressive for the naphthalene adsorption. Without electric field, the oxygen availability is the rate determining factor since the oxidation of adsorbed naphthalene on the catalyst surface is the lowest compared with the adsorption and oxygen regeneration process. Under the electric field, the conduction of electricity is through the occupation and reformation of oxygen vacancies by O ion, leading to highly improved oxygen mobility in the catalyst lattice. In addition, the formed Ce3+ in the electric field can easily be re-oxidized by the adjacent CuO, making oxygen species in CuO available for the naphthalene oxidation. Thus the catalytic performance was promoted due to the improved oxygen availability in the electric field and the optimized Cu loading is a balance between the adsorption ability and regeneration capability.
coredata.dc:title: Electric field promoted oxidation of naphthalene over Cu/Ce0.55Zr0.45O x catalysts at low temperature
